author: By Dan Barry
title: On a Storied Stretch of Fifth Avenue, a Symbol of Irish America Reels
description: The American Irish Historical Society’s mansion on Central Park has long symbolized the ascent of immigrants in the United States. It’s now on sale for $52 million, but many are citing mismanagement and asking the attorney general to intervene.
content: An exquisite Fifth Avenue townhouse of Gilded Age pedigree is on the market for $52 million. It features five stories, a curved terrace and a history that reads like a tragedy of manners, filled with grandeur and pride, pettiness and decay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Robert Gebeloff
title: In U.S. nursing homes, where Covid-19 killed scores, even reports of maggots and rape don’t dock five-star ratings.
description: Twelve years ago, the U.S. government introduced a powerful new tool to help people make a wrenching decision: which nursing home to choose for loved ones at their most vulnerable. Using a simple star rating — one being the worst, five the best — the system promised to distill reams of information and transform an emotional process into one based on objective, government-blessed metrics.
content: Twelve years ago, the U.S. government introduced a powerful new tool to help people make a wrenching decision: which nursing home to choose for loved ones at their most vulnerable. Using a simple star rating — one being the worst, five the best — the system promised to distill reams of information and transform an emotional process into one based on objective, government-blessed metrics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Can the World Learn From South Africa’s Vaccine Trials?
description: Vaccine trials are often done in wealthier countries. Scientists say the South Africa experience proves the value of trials in the global south.
content: In a year that has seesawed between astonishing gains and brutal setbacks on Covid-19, few moments were as sobering as the revelation last month that a coronavirus variant in South Africa was dampening the effect of one of the world’s most potent vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Refugee Flights Canceled as Biden Fails to Lift Trump Cutback
description: More than 715 refugees have postponed travel to the United States after waiting for years in camps. President Biden has pledged to welcome more but has left thousands in limbo.
content: More than 715 refugees from around the world who expected to start new lives in the United States have had their flights canceled in recent weeks because President Biden has postponed an overhaul of his predecessor’s sharp limits on new refugee admissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
title: Covid? What Covid? Taiwan Thrives as a Bubble of Normality.
description: The island has used its pandemic success to sell something scarce: life without fear of the coronavirus. Citizens have flocked home from abroad, helping to fuel an economic boom.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — As the coronavirus has upended lives and economies around the world, Taiwan has been an oasis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: The ‘21’ Club Isn’t Dead. Yet.
description: Its owner, LVMH, promises a reimagining of the space. But in the meantime almost 150 unionized employees have been laid off.
content: It should not have, but it came as a shock that the jockeys had vanished. There they’d stood outside the “21” Club on West 52nd Street for decades, 35 of them, with their cast metal arms upraised to grasp the reins of some invisible mount, their silks brightly painted in the colors of storied thoroughbred stables. Suddenly, then, they were gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Behind the Reporting of the Taliban’s Secret Prisons
description: A perilous trip to find out more about these brutal incarcerations led to a wrenching interview and something extremely rare on this job: a hug.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Oswaks
title: Over 3 Million People Took This Course on Happiness. Here’s What Some Learned.
description: It may seem simple, but it bears repeating: sleep, gratitude and helping other people.
content: The Yale happiness class, formally known as Psyc 157: Psychology and the Good Life, is one of the most popular classes to be offered in the university’s 320-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: From Crypto Art to Trading Cards, Investment Manias Abound
description: Each market frenzy seems crazier than the last. But all have the same roots.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — This past week, a trading card featuring the quarterback Tom Brady sold for a record $1.3 million. The total value of the cryptocurrency Bitcoin hit $1 trillion. And Christie’s sold a digital artwork by an artist known as Beeple for $69.3 million after bids started at just $100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Schumer and a Teachers’ Union Leader Secure Billions for Private Schools
description: The pandemic relief bill includes $2.75 billion for private schools. How it got there is an unlikely political tale, involving Orthodox Jewish lobbying, the Senate majority leader and a teachers’ union president.
content: WASHINGTON — Tucked into the $1.9 trillion pandemic rescue law is something of a surprise coming from a Democratic Congress and a president long seen as a champion of public education — nearly $3 billion earmarked for private schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Michael Forsythe
title: Whistle-Blower Says Credit Suisse Helped Clients Skip Taxes After Promising to Stop
description: A former bank employee contends that the Swiss bank continued to help American clients avoid taxes long after its 2014 plea deal with the U.S. government
content: Seven years after Credit Suisse promised federal prosecutors that it would stop helping rich Americans hide their wealth from tax collectors, a whistle-blower is contending that it continued to do just that, raising the possibility that the Swiss bank could face a fresh investigation and steep financial penalties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Born in Soviet Exile, They Might Die in a Russian One
description: Many victims of Stalin’s gulag are still unable to return to their families’ hometowns. Despite a court order, Moscow isn’t helping them.
content: NIZHNY ODES, Russia — Long lines of people waiting to buy milk, toilet paper and other essentials disappeared from Russia decades ago. But one line has only grown longer — the one Yevgeniya B. Shasheva has been waiting in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: The Imperious Rise and Accelerating Fall of Andrew Cuomo
description: Even as he tries to plot a political survival strategy in the face of sexual misconduct allegations, Mr. Cuomo is an object lesson on the dangers of kicking people on the way up.
content: Last spring, when the coronavirus outbreak was surging in New York, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s daily briefings became appointment television for many, as he authoritatively ticked through the latest statistics on infections, hospital beds and deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Bryson DeChambeau Keeps the Crowd Riveted at the Players Championship
description: The question of whether the big-hitting DeChambeau would pull out his driver seemed as compelling as the actual competition.
content: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Throughout the second round of the Players Championship on Friday, an entertaining crew of the world’s best golfers vied for the tournament lead. But for several hours, most fans were transfixed by a different matter: Whether Bryson DeChambeau would hit a prudent iron or take a mighty lash with his driver on hole after hole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Can Andrew Cuomo Continue to Lead?
description: The governor has lost his political allies and the public’s confidence.
content: Few political families have had more of an impact on New York politics than the Cuomos. Father and firstborn son both had public service woven deep in their DNA, and both developed a reputation for toughness in service of the common good and their own political ambitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: You’ll have to get up pretty early in the morning, in the dark, to solve this Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon acrostic.
content: ACROSTIC — If you’re here for hints, get ready to spring forward and finish this acrostic. That last sentence is kind of a spoiler, actually, especially if it reminds you (as it did me) that daylight saving happens this weekend; that’s the subject of the passage today. It’s from a book called “Spring Forward: The Annual Madness of Daylight Saving Time,” by Michael Downing, and it involves a proposal by an American founding father that long preceded electric light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: They All Laughed
description: What, us worry? We can get through this tough Jacob Stulberg puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Who all laughed? Maybe you all laughed, working on this quirky grid that features a venerable humor magazine and one of its most famous contributors. We’re looking at a real labor of love by Jacob Stulberg, a second-year law student at New York University, a 13-year veteran of the Times puzzle and a superfan of the magazine in question. How super? Check your back copies: If you have the December 1995 issue (No. 341), there’s a letter to the editor from our constructor, correcting the editorial misuse of the term “gluteus maximus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: A Drunken Hazing, a Fatal Fall and a Cornell Fraternity’s Silence
description: Antonio Tsialas was thriving in his first year at college. Then he was found dead in a gorge, and the fraternity that recruited him closed ranks. What happened is still a mystery.
content: Flavia Tomasello was overwhelmed by the smell of alcohol as she made her way into the Cornell University fraternity house where her missing son had last been seen. It was parents weekend, and she was supposed to have met him at the campus bookstore that morning, but he never showed up. By 10 p.m., he still wasn’t answering his phone. His friends hadn’t seen him all day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: At Kosovo Monastery, Nationalist Clamor Disturbs the Peace
description: The monastery’s Serbian Orthodox abbot says he is subject to “rabid nationalism” from all sides. His biggest headache: a land dispute with ethnic Albanians, whom he protected during the war in the 1990s.
content: DECAN, Kosovo — Inside the walls of Father Sava Janjic’s 14th-century monastery reign silence and calm, interrupted by the occasional soft footfall of the few monks remaining in this revered outpost of the Serbian Orthodox Church in a hostile western Kosovo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Kate Baer Is Speaking Truth. From Her Minivan.
description: Who says motherhood can’t be literary, even poetic?
content: Before the pandemic, when she could afford a babysitter, Kate Baer would write from a Panera Bread near her home in Hummelstown, Pa., where her favorite staffer, Annemarie, would save her the booth with the power outlet and didn’t mind if she brought her own food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Michael Levenson
title: Chris Harrison Replaced as ‘Bachelorette’ Host by 2 Former Contestants
description: Mr. Harrison, who acknowledged making comments dismissive of racism, will be replaced on the coming season by the first women to host the franchise, Tayshia Adams and Kaitlyn Bristowe.
content: Chris Harrison will not host the next season of “The Bachelorette” for the first time in the history of the franchise, which began as a guilty pleasure when it debuted in 2002 but has in recent years been criticized for its lack of diversity and insensitive handling of race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Coyote That Attacked Five in Bay Area Is Finally Caught
description: The animal, which had bitten five people, including two young children, near San Francisco over nearly eight months, was euthanized on Thursday.
content: The Bay Area’s long, furry nightmare is finally over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Leibovich
title: A Political Hurricane Blew Through Georgia. Now It’s Bracing for More.
description: The country’s most hotly contested state has calmed down after months of drama, court fights and national attention (even the death threats have slowed). But new storms are on the horizon.
content: ATLANTA — The death threats finally appeared to be subsiding, Brad Raffensperger was happy to report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: After a 28-Year Ban, Alabama Could Allow Yoga in Public Schools
description: “It’s just exercise,” said Jeremy Gray, a state lawmaker whose bill is making its way through the Legislature. But some people still say the practice has no place in the classroom.
content: For nearly three decades, teaching yoga in Alabama’s public schools has been forbidden by the state’s school board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Luis Palau, the ‘Billy Graham of Latin America,’ Dies at 86
description: He rose from preaching on street corners in Argentina to ministering to millions around the world, then focused his ministry on liberal corners of the U.S.
content: Luis Palau, who rose from preaching on street corners in Argentina to become one of the most significant evangelical leaders in the generation following his mentor, Billy Graham, died on Thursday at his home in Portland, Ore. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

title: TikTok and the Pop Music Rough Draft
description: The wildly popular platform has reshaped pop during the coronavirus pandemic, and changed how record labels grapple with unpredictable virality.
content: Most of the biggest pop music success stories of the last year — loosely the quarantine era in the United States — owe at least some of their success to TikTok, the social video app that’s become the most seamless and effective promotional mechanism in the music business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: Despite Covid Outbreaks, Youth Sports Played On
description: The coronavirus has spread at hockey rinks, basketball games and wrestling tournaments. But many experts, parents and participants believe that the benefits outweigh the risks.
content: NEW ORLEANS — As a coach in a sport where social distancing is impossible, Andrew Nicola said he did all he could to keep the students on his wrestling team safe during the pandemic — following rules on restricting spectators, disinfecting mats between rounds and requiring wrestlers to change into clean singlets between every match.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: The Other Kushner’s Next Move
description: Joshua Kushner is steering his venture capital firm out from under the shadow of his older brother — and the Trump administration.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: A Times Writer on Missing … The Times
description: Incredibly, we have all worked remotely for a year. But I’m homesick for our office.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Jason DeParle
title: Two Decades After the ‘End of Welfare,’ Democrats Are Changing Direction
description: The pandemic and a set of other economic and social forces changed the calculation for Democrats when it comes to government aid. The question now is how long the moment will last.
content: WASHINGTON — A quarter-century ago, a Democratic president celebrated “the end of welfare as we know it,” challenging the poor to exercise “independence” and espousing balanced budgets and smaller government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez and Sabrina Tavernise
title: Stimulus Bill Transforms Options For State and Local Governments
description: Once fearing fiscal disaster, governments are suddenly awash in their share of $350 billion available for projects and needs that previously seemed out of reach.
content: Richard F. Cortez, the top elected official in Hidalgo County, at the southern tip of Texas, is so full of anticipation for the federal stimulus money that is about to flow into his county that he has memorized the precise amount and happily recites it: “$212,702,647.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Will Republicans Pay a Price for Opposing the Stimulus?
description: It’s complicated. But so far, their messaging has been scattershot.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Robert Gebeloff
title: Maggots, Rape and Yet Five Stars: How U.S. Ratings of Nursing Homes Mislead the Public
description: Nursing homes have manipulated the influential star system in ways that have masked deep problems — and left them unprepared for Covid-19.
content: Twelve years ago, the U.S. government introduced a powerful new tool to help people make a wrenching decision: which nursing home to choose for loved ones at their most vulnerable. Using a simple star rating — one being the worst, five the best — the system promised to distill reams of information and transform an emotional process into one based on objective, government-blessed metrics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady
title: Ebola Survivor Infected Years Ago May Have Started New Outbreak
description: Genetic sequencing of virus samples from patients in Guinea suggest that the new outbreak is a continuation of the 2014-16 epidemic.
content: An Ebola outbreak now occurring in Guinea was almost certainly started by someone who survived West Africa’s historic 2014-16 epidemic, harbored the virus for at least five years and then transmitted it via semen to a sex partner, researchers reported on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China asks visa applicants to get inoculated with Chinese-made vaccines.
description: A new rule for foreigners applying in Hong Kong for visas gives preference to those who choose shots produced in China.
content: BEIJING — China raised the stakes in the international vaccine competition on Saturday, saying that foreigners wishing to enter the Chinese mainland from Hong Kong will face fewer paperwork requirements if they are inoculated with Chinese-made coronavirus vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Patrick Dupond, French Ballet Virtuoso, Dies at 61
description: Renowned as both a star dancer and the director of the Paris Opera Ballet, he was a household name in France from an early age.
content: Patrick Dupond, a star dancer and former director of the Paris Opera Ballet who won worldwide renown in the 1980s and ’90s for his virtuosity, glittering technique and flamboyant personality, died on March 5 in Soissons, France. He was 61.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Holder and Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Global vaccination rates are on the rise, but many countries have yet to start.
description: North America and Europe are far outpacing most countries in Asia and Africa.
content: More than 345 million doses of Covid-19 vaccines have been administered worldwide in the three months since mass inoculation began in December, but there is still a huge disparity in the vaccination rates between countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino and Asadullah Timory
title: How a Longstanding Rivalry Spiraled Into 5 Deaths Between 2 Families
description: In Afghanistan, a rise in targeted attacks that the government seems unable to stop has also encouraged the settling of old scores through vendetta killings.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Bismillah Adel Aymaq, a prominent radio journalist in western Afghanistan, was preparing a groundbreaking report late last year that accused a provincial council member of corruption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: How Democrats Hope to Press Their Advantage on the Stimulus
description: Our political reporter lays out Democrats’ messaging goals for the relief bill as they eye the midterms.
content: President Biden signed his $1.9 trillion coronavirus relief bill into law yesterday, a move that will send $1,400 stimulus checks to many Americans, strengthen a wide range of social programs and step up investment in vaccine distribution. A few hours later, he went on national television to trumpet the achievement. And this afternoon, he celebrated it in a Rose Garden ceremony, joined by Democratic leaders in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Announcer Caught on Open Mic Using Racial Slur at Basketball Game
description: The announcer cursed and used a slur as students knelt during the national anthem before a high school tournament game in Oklahoma. He later apologized and blamed his diabetes for the outburst.
content: A sports announcer at an Oklahoma high school basketball game uttered a racial slur into a live microphone as players on the court knelt during the national anthem on Thursday night, prompting widespread outrage and condemnation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Banned Vigil for Sarah Everard Becomes Large Anti-Violence Rally Instead
description: Thousands of protesters rallied in South London near where the 33-year-old woman was last seen, despite police warnings that the event would be unlawful because of coronavirus restrictions.
content: LONDON — Thousands of people gathered in south London on Saturday for a vigil in tribute to Sarah Everard, the 33-year-old marketing executive whose killing has touched off a national reckoning over violence against women, despite police warnings that the event would be unlawful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Hundreds of Tesla workers tested positive for the virus after Elon Musk reopened a plant, data shows.
description: The plant, in Fremont, Calif., resumed operations last May in defiance of guidelines issued by local public health officials.
content: More than 400 workers at a Tesla plant in California tested positive for the coronavirus between May and December, according to public health data released by a transparency website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: ‘I’d Much Rather Be in Florida’
description: Floridians are out and about and pandemic restrictions have been lifted. There’s just one problem: The virus never went away.
content: MIAMI — Other than New York, no big city in the United States has been struggling with more coronavirus cases in recent weeks than Miami. But you would hardly know that if you lived here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: At least 7 Covid-19 patients die in Jordan because of an oxygen shortage, a growing problem around the world.
description: The country’s health minister and the director of the hospital where the seven died were forced to resign.
content: At least seven people died at a hospital in Jordan on Saturday after it ran out of oxygen, according to Jordanian news reports, prompting an outcry in the kingdom, a visit to the hospital by King Abdullah II and the resignations of the country’s health minister and the hospital’s director.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: 17 Reasons to Let the Economic Optimism Begin
description: A reporter who has tracked decades of gloomy trends sees things lining up for roaring growth.
content: The 21st-century economy has been a two-decade series of punches in the gut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
title: Taiwan, a Covid-19 outlier, is selling something scarce: life without fear of the virus.
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan — As the coronavirus has upended lives and economies around the world, Taiwan has been an oasis.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — As the coronavirus has upended lives and economies around the world, Taiwan has been an oasis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: After Breonna Taylor’s Death, Black Engagement in Kentucky Politics Soared
description: “Her door being kicked in was our door being kicked in,” a former state representative said as the first anniversary of Ms. Taylor’s death approached. “It really has transformed everything.”
content: Exactly one year ago, a young woman died as a barrage of police gunfire ripped through the walls of her modest apartment in Louisville, Ky. For months, her death went largely unrecognized.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: U.S. Takes Step to Use Vaccine for Diplomacy
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 13, 2021.
content: “It’s time for U.S. leaders to ask themselves: When this pandemic is over, do we want the world to remember America’s leadership helping distribute lifesaving vaccines, or will we leave that to others?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Concerns over the AstraZeneca vaccine. Older people are happier. The week in Covid-19 news.
description: A handful of countries in Europe are shying away from the vaccine developed by AstraZeneca and the University of Oxford. Demark, Norway and Iceland said Thursday they would halt its use while European drug regulators examine the possibility of a link to blood-clotting issues. They emphasized that they were just being cautious and that there is no evidence of any causal link, and global health authorities confirmed support for the vaccine.
content: A handful of countries in Europe are shying away from the vaccine developed by AstraZeneca and the University of Oxford. Demark, Norway and Iceland said Thursday they would halt its use while European drug regulators examine the possibility of a link to blood-clotting issues. They emphasized that they were just being cautious and that there is no evidence of any causal link, and global health authorities confirmed support for the vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nuwer
title: Protecting Lions Aids the Whole Food Chain? Think Again
description: The assumption that adding apex predators to wildlife parks in South Africa benefits smaller animals is in need of more testing, scientists say.
content: Tourists visit South Africa’s wildlife reserves to see lions and leopards, not civets and servals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: Can France’s Far Right Rise to Power? One Mayor Shows How.
description: In the southern city of Perpignan, voters who had long built a dam against the far right turned in the last election. Some wonder whether it’s a harbinger of things to come.
content: PERPIGNAN, France — Riding high in the polls ahead of the next presidential election, feeling they’ve won the battle over ideas, smelling blood in the Élysée Palace, leaders of France’s far right cocked their eyes across the land at perhaps the one thing standing between them and power: beavers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: After Capitol Riot, Lawmakers Chafe at Security Measures
description: There is bipartisan interest in removing fencing around the Capitol and dismissing the National Guard troops deployed there, but law enforcement officials fear new threats.
content: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers in both parties are increasingly agitating to scale back the security measures put in place around the Capitol in the aftermath of the Jan. 6 riot, intensifying a debate over how to balance safety concerns and public access to a building that is a symbol of democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Statement of Inevitability
description: Rise, shine and dig in to what John Guzzetta’s whipped up.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — We have a nice multigrain loaf of a themeless today, filling, with lots of diverse nuts and seeds throughout. John Guzzetta is an all-purpose constructor, but the bulk of his efforts come on Fridays and Saturdays; this feels like a Saturday to me in scope, but solves pretty smoothly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brianna Holt
title: Tony Hawk and Family Hit the Open Road During Quarantine
description: Around this time last year, the professional skateboarder and his wife, Catherine Goodman, were having dinner at the Oscars. Now they’re enjoying quality time on R.V. trips with their children.
content: In early July, Tony Hawk and Catherine Goodman, rounded up their six children, Riley Hawk, 28, Spencer Hawk, 21, Miles Goodman, 21, Keegan Hawk, 19, Calvin Goodman, 18, and Kadence Hawk, 12, for a road trip across the western United States in an R.V.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can You Have a Puppy and Nice Furniture?
description: People with nice furniture do have dogs. So how do they do it?
content: Q: My partner and I are in a four-legged standoff. He wants a puppy because, “Puppies!” I don’t because we just decorated our wonderful Cobble Hill apartment. I can already see a puppy turning the wood legs of our coffee table into his favorite chew toy. And what about our poor sisal rug? My partner insists that people with dogs have nice furniture, and ours will survive if we train our puppy. I’m not so sure. Who’s right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chloe Pang and Valeriya Safronova
title: One Year Together, Apart
description: The pandemic redefined relationships and self-reliance.
content: In the year since the pandemic began, people learned to be together while apart and navigated the pain of feeling apart while together. Screens, small and large, became crucial links to the rest of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Spring Is Coming
description: Asparagus tarts and stir-fries are on the horizon.
content: We’re setting the clocks forward tonight, a sign that spring is (finally) around the corner. Another sign? NYT Cooking readers are saving asparagus recipes to their recipe boxes: Melissa Clark’s asparagus, goat cheese and tarragon tart (above) and Ali Slagle’s turmeric-black pepper chicken with asparagus were among our most popular recipes this week. Readers also loved Millie Peartree’s sheet-pan roasted mushrooms and spinach and Ali Slagle’s creamy braised white beans. Make any one of them, and get excited for the new season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: Sorry About Your Sleep
description: A group of U.S. senators has joined the ranks of those who want to abolish daylight saving time, which has roots in cost-cutting strategies of the late 19th century.
content: Hello. You may be here to learn when is daylight saving time, or what is the time that we’re saving, or why does daylight saving time even exist.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Let's Stress-Eat Some Chips Together
description: Sam Anderson says this snack will rescue us from the very worst things on our screens. Listen to his case and sail off into the salty seas of decadent gluttony, guilt-free.
content: Sam Anderson says this snack will rescue us from the very worst things on our screens. Listen to his case and sail off into the salty seas of decadent gluttony, guilt-free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Leatherby
title: Despite Encouraging Downward Trend, U.S. Covid Deaths Remain High
description: Nearly 1,500 people are still dying of Covid-19 every day in the United States, a number that is lower than peaks seen last spring and early this year but exceeds the highest rate in July.
content: Nearly 1,500 people are still dying of Covid-19 every day in the United States, a number that is lower than peaks seen last spring and early this year but exceeds the highest rate in July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Protesters Defy Covid Restrictions to Rally for Slain London Woman
description: Thousands of people gathered at Clapham Common on Saturday, the London park near where Sarah Everard, 33, was last seen alive. Her death led to an outpouring of anger and solidarity over violence against women.
content: Thousands of people gathered at Clapham Common on Saturday, the London park near where Sarah Everard, 33, was last seen alive. Her death led to an outpouring of anger and solidarity over violence against women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Microsoft Executive Says Tech Consolidation Threatens Journalism
description: Brad Smith, Microsoft’s president, told Congress he supports the Journalism Competition and Protection Act, which empowers news publishers to collectively bargain with online platforms like Facebook and Google.
content: Brad Smith, Microsoft’s president, told Congress he supports the Journalism Competition and Protection Act, which empowers news publishers to collectively bargain with online platforms like Facebook and Google.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: George Floyd’s Family Settles Suit for $27 Million
description: Minneapolis agreed on Friday to pay $27 million to the family of George Floyd, the Black man whose killing by a white police officer was caught on video and ignited months of nationwide protests.
content: Minneapolis agreed on Friday to pay $27 million to the family of George Floyd, the Black man whose killing by a white police officer was caught on video and ignited months of nationwide protests.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Vaccine Maker’s Investment: Emergent BioSolutions Responds
description: The company takes issue with an article in The Times.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 13, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 13, 2021.
content: An article on Thursday about the passage of the stimulus bill by Congress misattributed the quotation “The American people are going to see an American comeback this year, but it won’t be because of this liberal bill.” It was from Representative Kevin McCarthy of California, not Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky.
source.name: The New York Times
